qas.question: How does Einstein advocate Mach's principle?
How Einstein's theory compared to Leibniz's?
What is considered contrary to idealist beliefs in regards to space?

answers.text: objects exist independently of the mind

qas.question: What do idealist believe can not exist independent of the mind?
Space and what have a dependent existence?

context: <b4_0>Einstein<b4_0/> <a0_0>partially<a0_0/> advocates <b3_0>Mach<b3_0/>'s principle in that distant stars explain inertia because they provide the gravitational field against which acceleration and inertia occur. But <a1_0>contrary<a1_0/> to Leibniz's account, this warped space-time is as integral a part of an object as are its other defining characteristics, such as volume and mass. If one holds, contrary to idealist beliefs, that <a2_0><b5_0>objects<b5_0/> exist independently of the mind<a2_0/>, it seems that relativistics commits them to also hold that space and <b6_0>temporality<b6_0/> have exactly the same type of independent existence.
